abstract.p: Struggle for Ashton Mining of Australia is extended as De Beers raises its offer by 45 percent, beating bid by rival, Rio Tinto; De Beers offers 2.28 Australian dollars, for total of $400 million; Rio Tinto had offered 1.85 Australian dollars (S)

block.p: The seesaw struggle for Ashton Mining of Australia was extended as De Beers raised its offer by 45 percent, trumping a bid by its rival, Rio Tinto. De Beers offered 2.28 Australian dollars, about $1.23, a share, for a total of $400 million. Rio Tinto had offered 1.85 Australian dollars. De Beers, the world's largest miner and marketer of diamonds, covets Ashton, which holds a 40 percent stake in the Argyle mine in Australia. Argyle, which yields the low-quality stones used for cutting and grinding, is the largest deposit of diamonds in the world. Rio Tinto holds the remaining 60 percent of Argyle.
